reasoning: [Specific Program Not Verified] Paper mentions 'Compassion International Child Sponsorship Program' but search could not confirm this as graduation program: Perplexity search result: The Compassion International Child Sponsorship Program provides sponsored children with access to education, healthcare, nutrition, and vocational training through local church partners, but it is not designed as a 'graduation program' in the technical sense defined by organizations like BRAC, J-PAL, or IPA. Graduation programs typically have time-limited, multi-component interventions including direct cash transfers and productive asset packages to help ultra-poor households build sustainable livelihoods. Compassion's model emphasizes holistic child development, including educational scholarships, vocational training, and psychosocial support, but does not systematically provide ongoing direct cash transfers/stipends to children or families. Instead, sponsorship funds are pooled and disbursed to partner centers, not handed directly to beneficiaries.[7][8] Regarding productive assets, individual cases (such as providing laptops for vocational training[2]) do occur, but there is no evidence that provision of productive assets is a standard program feature. In some cases, special interventions or scholarships are given (i.e., tuition payments, tools for vocational graduates[2]), but this is not comparable to the productive asset packages typical of graduation programs. | Graduation: NO, Cash: NO, Assets: UNCLEAR | Confidence: HIGH | Sources: https://www.compassion.com/sponsor_a_child/what-is-child-sponsorship/, https://www.compassion.com/for-sponsors/stories/the-graduate-most-likely-to.htm, https://www.compassion.com/for-sponsors/stories/what-happens-to-my-sponsored-child-after-they-graduate.htm
